results.title: The New councillor
results.brief_description: Through the experiences of Richards, a newly elected borough councillor, shows the varied activities of a typical councillor - the people’s relationship both with the people who elected him and the permanent officials who carry out the policy laid down by the council.

results.title: New cords for old, and the golden rule
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Australian Instructional Films and Instructional Films for S E C
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Electricity Safety”.
Do not keep old damaged electrical cords, and never try to repair them. Common causes of accidents are frayed cords, and badly repaired cords, broken plugs, and two cord flexes used instead of three cord flexes. Once insulation becomes worn or damaged wires are exposed which may cause shocks. Hows correct way of wiring new plugs and recommends that it is a job for an expert.

results.title: People in the country
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The New China No. 2”.
Shows views of life and work on a farming commune near Peking, varied rural scenes, temples and other places of interest, and National Day celebrations including a procession and folk dancing displays.

results.title: Neorealism
results.brief_description: Documentary exploring the Italian film movement, Neo-realism, which developed during World War II and dealt with moral, social and political problems in real locations. Includes interviews with Roberto Rossellini, Vittorio De Sica, Michaelangelo Antonioni, Pier Paolo Pasolini and Bernardo Bertolucci. Features film clips from Rossellini’s “Rome, open city” and “Paisa” and De Sica’s “Umberto D”.

results.title: Nebule
results.creator_credit: Bernard Longpre, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this animated film a black line becomes a magic cord to serve a small child’s fancy. In Nebule’s hands it becomes whatever he wills and the metamorphoses, played out against a soft, pastelcolored background, encompass the world of a child’s fears and fancies. A film without narration.

results.title: The Nazis strike
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra and United States. War Dept.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Why we fight”.
This unnerving film examines the growth of Hitler’s Nazi Party, which became mankind’s single most destructive force. Includes Hitler’s closest aides and key figures, the denouncing of all religious belief as weak and petty, and the atrocities which promised German world domination. Concludes with the invasions of Austria, Czechoslovakia and Poland. This film was originally intended for the orientation of members of the armed forces during the war. Narrated by Walter Huston and Captain Anthony Veiller. Editing, Major William Hornbeck. Music, Dimitri Tiomkin.

results.title: Nature's plan
results.creator_credit: George Brewer, John C. Gibbs, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and The Conservation Foundation
results.brief_description: This film describes the water cycle as Nature’s plan for providing all living things with life-giving water. Describes how water form the ocean is drawn into the air by evaporation, formed into clouds, condensed to water, delivered to the earth and returned to the ocean. Natural and time-lapse photography combine with animated drawings to clarify the mechanics of the water cycle and to describe and contrast various water cycle patterns in North America.

results.title: Music of India: drums
results.creator_credit: A. Bhaskar Rao, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: Shows the variety of drums used in the music and dances of India. Presents the intricate compositions played on the Pakhawaj, Mridang and Tabla by renowned artists.

results.title: The Music of a modern navy
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Navy Office. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: In a fast moving “cinema verite” style film the bands of the Royal Australian Navy play jazz, pops, country and western, Latin American and martial music. In changing locales, such as Kings Cross, Australia Square, the Royal Brisbane Show, in New South Wales country towns, on board ship and in Naval establishments they perform and entertain.

results.title: The Music makers
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Music makers from all over Australia come each year to the National Fitness Council’s Music Camp formerly held at Geelong Grammar School. Some are professional musicians or students of music, others play only in their spare time, but all combine their talents to produce orchestras and chamber music groups. Performances by the players include selections from Handel, Sibelius and Dohnanyi. Photographed by Frank Bagnall.
